theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on mitochondrial ROS generation as primary source of free radicals causing aging and the role of antioxidants targeting mitochondria.
Emphasizes oxidative damage from ROS generated during metabolism, antioxidant enzyme defenses, and energy restriction enhancing mitochondrial antioxidant capacity.
Highlights mitochondria as main ROS source and target, decline in antioxidant defenses, and oxidative damage accumulation driving brain aging.
Describes ROS from metabolism causing oxidative damage accumulation leading to cellular and organismal aging, consistent with mitochondrial ROS origin.
Focuses on ROS from mitochondria, balance with antioxidant defenses, and links to longevity and dietary restriction effects.
Emphasizes mitochondrial dysfunction as primary ROS source, oxidative stress accumulation, and antioxidant defense imbalance driving aging.
Focuses on oxidative DNA damage in mitochondrial and nuclear DNA, mitochondrial dysfunction, and decline in repair and antioxidant defenses.
Describes mitochondrial vulnerability to ROS, oxidative damage causing immune system senescence, and antioxidant defense imbalance.
Details mitochondrial ROS production, decline in cytosolic antioxidant enzymes, compensatory mitochondrial antioxidant increase, and oxidative damage in myocardial aging.
Focuses on oxygen radical formation and oxidative damage accumulation in brain aging despite reduced radical formation.
General free radical accumulation from metabolism causing damage to biomolecules and driving aging and disease risk.
Describes ROS accumulation causing damage and antioxidant defense as anti-aging strategy, consistent with mitochondrial ROS origin.
Focuses on ROS accumulation from metabolism causing oxidative stress and aging, with antioxidant defenses modulating lifespan.
Describes ROS as aging drivers causing oxidative damage, with antioxidant enzymes influencing aging rate.
Focuses on endogenous free radical damage impairing immune function and antioxidant inhibitors ameliorating aging effects.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: NADPH-Dependent Antioxidant Defense Free Radical Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Highlights role of NADPH and G6PD enzyme in providing reducing power for antioxidant defenses that detoxify ROS and modulate aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: ROS-Induced Cellular Senescence Free Radical Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on ROS causing cellular senescence via signaling pathways (p53/p21, p16INK4a/Rb), especially in stem cells, linking oxidative stress to organismal aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Oxidative DNA Damage and Repair Free Radical Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Emphasizes oxidative DNA damage accumulation and decline in base excision repair capacity in neurons as key aging mechanisms.
Describes synergistic damage from free radicals and Maillard reaction glycation products (AGEs), amplifying oxidative and glycation damage in aging.
Focuses on oxidative degradation of connective tissue glycoproteins leading to amyloid fibril formation and aging-related pathology, inhibited by antioxidants.
Emphasizes free radical-induced lipid peroxidation as fundamental cause of systemic aging and antioxidant mitigation by vitamin E.
Focuses on lipid peroxidation products causing membrane damage and cellular dysfunction contributing to aging.
Highlights lipid peroxidation and lipofuscin accumulation as markers of oxidative damage and aging, modulated by dietary restriction.
Describes lipid peroxidation and antioxidant enzymes as key factors in oxidative damage accumulation and lipofuscin pigment buildup in aging.
Focuses on ROS-induced damage to lipids and membranes in hair aging, with antioxidant defenses declining with age.
Emphasizes lipid peroxidation-derived aldehydes causing tissue damage and fibrosis in aging, modulated by dietary fat and oxidative stress.
